S4.T1.caption: Table 1:  Word error rates  e y subscript 𝑒 𝑦 e_{y} , reported as a percentage. Rows are grouped by partition and NLL bin; columns by model. The  all  rows contain the error rates over the entire partition, without binning.
references: Table 1 lists average error rates, without noise. In general, GMM-3 has the most errors, then TDNN-3, TDNN-4, W2V2-B, and W2V2-L the fewest. Further, as expected [7, 9], error rates increase as a function of NLL. Finally, we note wide disparity between LibriSpeech and CORAAL.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2:  Estimated  k 𝑘 k  and bootstrapped 95% confidence intervals. The first block lists fit  k 𝑘 k  values per partition, averaged over models. The second block is per model, averaged over partitions. The  all  row aggregates all models per partition.
references: Table 2 lists k𝑘k by partition, model, and in aggregate. Columns represent the choice of ``context'' bin ecsubscript𝑒𝑐e_{c}, which is either LP or HP; the ``isolated'' bin is always ZP. We concentrate on in-domain (LS) first. In all cells, k>1𝑘1k>1, and confidence intervals do not include k=1𝑘1k=1: textual predictability plays a role in error rates. Furthermore, k𝑘k is higher when fit to the HP error rates than the LP rates—k𝑘k increases as a function of predictability. Finally, on HP, there is a divide between models using a 3-gram LM versus the more sophisticated models, particularly W2V2-L, with the latter yielding higher k𝑘k values.

Next we consider the out-of-domain (CL) data. First, Table 3 tabulates the proportion of utterances per partition captured in each bin. The two LS partitions have similar proportions in each bin. On CORAAL, the vast majority of the data remain in the HP and LP bins, in line with the observation of Koenecke et al. [2] that CORAAL and LibriSpeech transcriptions are more similar than different. Nevertheless, the mass shifts toward the ZP bin, raising the possibility that CORAAL error rates could be affected by textual predictions, as per Martin and Tang [1]. In the absence of previous studies, it is difficult to say how big such an effect could be: while in-domain k𝑘k values are greater than 111, they are far from the catastrophic k=500𝑘500k=500 case. Returning, then, to Table 2, we recall that, in cases of mismatch between Qs​y​ssubscript𝑄𝑠𝑦𝑠Q_{sys} and the new domain Pt​e​s​tsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡P_{test}, we expect k𝑘k to go down, approaching 111. In fact, in general, k𝑘k values are higher on CORAAL. Thus, we reach a similar conclusion to Koenecke et al. [2]: when applying (these) ASR systems to African-American English, the effect of textual domain shift is limited—at least as measured by our approach. Further research should be done to explore the relation between in-domain k𝑘k and out-of-domain performance.

To better illustrate this, in Figure 3 we compare the point-wise estimates of k𝑘k versus isolated error rates eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} on W2V2-L. The two fitted values of k𝑘k to LS-C are shown as lines. Were Eq. 4 a perfect fit, the point-wise estimates would follow horizontal lines: rather, point-wise k𝑘k changes as a function of eisubscript𝑒𝑖e_{i} (SNR), peaking at around 80-90% errors. Generally, the fitted k𝑘k tends to match the point-wise estimates for ei≈0.5subscript𝑒𝑖0.5e_{i}\approx 0.5. We reason that point-wise k𝑘k in this region are the best approximation for the global fit.
Since error rates rarely fall below 50% on CORAAL, its k𝑘k values in Table 2 are likely inflated. Nonetheless, as Fig. 3 illustrates, point-wise k𝑘k on CL routinely match or exceed LS, indicating no less an impact of textual predictability.

S4.T3.caption: Table 3:  Proportion of partition captured by each NLL bin (%). The  total  column sums each row.
references: Next we consider the out-of-domain (CL) data. First, Table 3 tabulates the proportion of utterances per partition captured in each bin. The two LS partitions have similar proportions in each bin. On CORAAL, the vast majority of the data remain in the HP and LP bins, in line with the observation of Koenecke et al. [2] that CORAAL and LibriSpeech transcriptions are more similar than different. Nevertheless, the mass shifts toward the ZP bin, raising the possibility that CORAAL error rates could be affected by textual predictions, as per Martin and Tang [1]. In the absence of previous studies, it is difficult to say how big such an effect could be: while in-domain k𝑘k values are greater than 111, they are far from the catastrophic k=500𝑘500k=500 case. Returning, then, to Table 2, we recall that, in cases of mismatch between Qs​y​ssubscript𝑄𝑠𝑦𝑠Q_{sys} and the new domain Pt​e​s​tsubscript𝑃𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡P_{test}, we expect k𝑘k to go down, approaching 111. In fact, in general, k𝑘k values are higher on CORAAL. Thus, we reach a similar conclusion to Koenecke et al. [2]: when applying (these) ASR systems to African-American English, the effect of textual domain shift is limited—at least as measured by our approach. Further research should be done to explore the relation between in-domain k𝑘k and out-of-domain performance.
